org.svvrl.goal.core.aut.fsa
Class InputSequence

java.lang.Object
  org.svvrl.goal.core.aut.fsa.InputSequence
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class InputSequence
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

An InputSequence is a string uvvv..., denoted by u{v}, where u is a finite prefix and v is the infinite part. There is also a pointer that can be used to indicate where the current input sequence has been consumed.

Author:
Ming-Hsien Tsai

InputSequence

public InputSequence(java.lang.String str,
                     boolean inf,
                     AlphabetType type,
                     java.lang.String[] alphabet)
Constructs this input sequence from a string. The string will be split into symbols according to a specified alphabet.

Parameters:
str - a string
inf - true if the string represents an infinite word
type - an alphabet type
alphabet - an alphabet

InputSequence

public InputSequence(java.lang.String str,
                     boolean inf)
Constructor with a formatted string and a boolean indicating whether the string represents an infinite word or not. An infinite word is formatted in the following form: u { v } where u and v are sequences of symbols separated by spaces. If a symbol contains a space, it should be enclosed by parentheses. If the word is a finite word, it does not have the { v } part.

Parameters:
str - a string representing an infinite or finite input sequence
inf - true if the input string represents an infinite input sequence, for example (p ~q)(p ~q) { (p q) (~p ~q) } where (p ~q)(p ~q) is the finite prefix and { (p q) (~p ~q) } is the infinite suffix

getPosition

public int getPosition()
Returns the relative position of the pointer. The symbols after this pointer are symbols to be consumed.

toStringWithIndicator

public java.lang.String toStringWithIndicator()
Returns the string representation of this input sequence with a pointer indicating the current position. Unlike toExpandedString(), the suffix will not be expanded.

Returns:
the string representation of this input sequence with a pointer indicating the current position

toExpandedString

public java.lang.String toExpandedString()
Returns the input sequence with the pointer indicating the current position in the input sequence. If the suffix has been consumed more than once, the suffix will be expanded.

Returns:
a string representing the input sequence with the pointer indicating the current position

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
Returns true if this word is equal to another word after expanding the prefix with the consumed suffix. If two words are equal, they have the same position in the words.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
obj - an object
Returns:
true if this word is equal to another word after expanding the prefix with the consumed suffix

equalsWithoutExpansion

public boolean equalsWithoutExpansion(java.lang.Object obj)
Returns true if this word is equal to another word, that is, they have the same prefix, suffix, and position in the words.

Parameters:
obj - an object
Returns:
true if this word is equal to another word
